The thirteenth-century pottery types discussed here are now identified as: proto-maiolica, a tin-glazed polychrome ware imported from southern Italy and Sicily; Port St-Symeon ware, a polychrome graffita (or sgraffiato) ware, produced in the region of Antioch; and various types of graffita and slip-painted ware imported from Cyprus. line 17: The lower courses of the north-east curtain wall, underlying that of the Rom an-Byzantine period, now seem unlikely to be part of the Second Wall described by Josephus. Some would identify them as belonging to the Third Wall, which was begun by Herod Agrippa I and ran from the Hippicus Tower north to the Tower of Psephinus

The Second Wall seems to have run from a point on the First Wall some distance east of the Hippicus Tower, northward as far as the modern Damascus Gate, then north-eastward curving to the south-east to meet the Antonia Fortress, located at the north-western corner of the Temple Mount; it thus enclosed the market area occupying the Tyropoeon Valley in the angle between the north (First) wall of the Upper City and the west wall of the Temple enclosure (see Bahat
